OR

The Avengers return from months of missions to find a child fast asleep on the lounge, with Tony snoring beside him. A mystery ensues.
Is Tony Stark a father? (It looks like it!) How have they never discovered the kid until now? I mean, Iron Man has always been good at keeping secrets, but a whole CHILD?

Rhodey could trace the shock residually plastered through every crease and curve of the other man’s face. Natasha still had a particularly pensive expression, sure, but Clint was floored. He looked like he had a concussion.

Maybe he did. Maybe that was a side effect of finding Tony Stark asleep on the couch next to a kid.

“He’s yours, isn’t he?” Rhodey asked quietly. “Your son.”

Tony opened and closed his mouth. Like a fish. “No?”

Clint leant forward to end the recording, but now that Tony was finished talking the quiet ‘beep!’ the phone made was highly audible.

“Oops,” he whispered, and quickly sent the video off to the Rogue Avengers’ group chat, with the caption, ‘Proof Stark has a son’.

Sam flew through something sticky and flailed around in the air for a second before righting himself. “What was that?” he spluttered. He recognised the feeling, but; “a spiderweb? What the fuck?”

The door to the lab slid mechanically open, to reveal a genius-billionaire-playboy-pilanthropist-possibly-dad according to the team’s conspiracy theories; and a slender, surprised-faced teen with brown curls standing awkwardly half-behind him.

Maybe it was better that the Rogues didn’t sit in on this particular board meeting.

At least it wasn’t as bad as the time he jumped onto the ceiling by accident because his pencil had rolled to the very edge of the table and the back of his neck felt like a bomb was about to go off.

“Colonel Rhodes has informed you on multiple occasions that you do not have to force yourself into threatening or vulnerable situations, but he encourages you to converse with Steve Rogers, as it may be a healthy way to resolve your emotions.”

“I’m already awake,” Peter cut in suddenly, without moving his head.

Yep. That was a voice Steve recognised, holy shit. Conspiracy confirmed.

text:
The night mist cleared. City lights glowed against the glass and steel facades of the skyscrapers.

“30 minutes to landing,” the speakers crackled.

“And do elephants produce milk?” Clint asked. He swallowed a mouthful of gummy bears before continuing with, “did woolly mammoth’s give milk? Did cave people ever make mammoth’s cheese?”

They were close enough to watch the plane’s reflection glide around on the dark patches of the city, broken by the glass into little pieces. “Hell, what is wrong with you, featherhead?” Natasha snorted from her stance by the window.

The man giggled. “Can you imagine little cave men milking their woolly mammoths?”

“No,” Sam replied, a traumatised note to his voice. “And I never thought I ever would until this conversation.”

“I think that’s enough candy for you now.” Steve scooped up the bowl, glanced at it once, and made the wisest decision – which was passing it immediately into the arms of the person sitting to his left.

“Hey!” Bucky complained. “How did I end up with custody of the most prized possession on the goddamn plane?”

“That baby’s all yours,” Steve grinned, and leaned over to brush his boyfriend’s lips. “Keep it safe.”

Rolling his eyes at the couple, Sam put up a sneaky hand. Another few handfuls of (almost) pure sugar disappeared. Bucky scowled protectively, shoved him away, and held the bowl closer. It nestled perfectly in the crook of his metal arm.

Natasha had forgotten how large and bright New York could be. The wet black sky surrounding the small jet was the greatest contrast it could be to the golden metropolis sprawled out below. She touched a fingertip to the cold glass window. A quiet voice behind her said, “it will be good to be back.”

Bruce watched Natasha as she pictured Tony Stark’s indignant face when the Avengers told him they hadn’t waited for his private jet to pick them up from the airport, instead renting a small charter. The vote had been unanimous – none of the Avengers would choose waiting for a comfortable flight over getting to the Tower sooner. Natasha’s mouth twisted upward. “Yes,” she told Bruce. “It will be good to be back.”

“You did tell Tony when we’re due to arrive, didn’t you?” Bucky asked, slightly worried.

Steve screwed up his nose. “Yes, and he said he had a project to work on but he’d try crawling out of his lab at some point to say hello.”

“His words or yours?” Clint laughed.

“It’s almost 3 in the morning.” Bucky sounded surprised. “Does he sleep, like, ever?”

The Avengers shook their heads. “Guy runs on coffee,” Bruce explained.

“20 minutes to landing,” said the speakers from the corner of the ceiling. “You want me to drop you at the airport?”

“Avengers Tower, Stark Industries,” Natasha remedied. “There’ll be a small runway.”

“Yes, ma’am,” the pilot replied. Natasha left her seat and casually swiped the bowl of candy from Bucky. “In that case, 5 minutes to landing.”

“Look,” Sam supplied, “I can see the Tower.”

It glittered silver. Avengers Tower easily dwarfed the rest of the block, smooth sides soaring higher than the boxy apartments and offices surrounding. It was an elegant shape, Natasha mused, crunching on candy. As much as a building could have grace and poise.

Hell, she was tired. It was getting to the point where the constant weight of the spare dagger strapped to her leg was an ache rather than a reassurance. Where even her fingerless gloves felt like they were weighing her down.

She flicked her gaze to the others. Yeah, they were tired, too. Forget suitcases, those were body-bags under Bruce’s calm eyes. And the rest of the team who weren’t hyped up on sugar (read: just Rhodey) had dull expressions and slumped shoulders. The last five chaotic months had seen mission after mission, only remotely assisted by Tony, taking them far and wide and beyond by never with a chance to break.

Natasha couldn’t wait to just collapse in her room and pass out. Not that she’d ever let anybody know that. The Black Widow retained her dignity now matter how exhausted she became, please and thank you.

Oh but hell, she was tired.

The plane shuddered slightly as they landed. Natasha balanced the bowl of food on her knees with, to her credit, only slightly less agility than as per usual. None of the candies spilled to the floor, so the woman stood and began moving toward the door.

“Wow, Nat, slow down,” Clint began. She turned loose a frostily unimpressed look. “I mean,” he stammered, “we haven’t even stopped moving completely yet.”

“Hey, I agree with Natasha,” Rhodes said. He shot the low ceiling a dark glance and rubbed the back of his neck. “Get me the hell off this plane.”

“Language,” Bucky pointed out with a snort, nudging Steve.

Eventually the door was unlocked and the Avengers clambered down the makeshift stairs one at a time. It was relieving to escape the cramped space and suck in deep breaths of cold (and polluted) night air.

The pilot unloaded their luggage onto the smooth concrete. There wasn’t much of it: just a small suitcase or two between them and various duffel bags of different sizes and colours. Steve thanked her and the woman, obviously uncomfortable with the knowledge that she’d just flown seven superheroes to the private runway above Stark Industries, disappeared back inside the plane. The team picked up their luggage (a little unenthusiastically) and turned to face the glass double doors.

Tony wasn’t waiting for them.

Granted, they weren’t exactly expecting it. Okay, let’s be fair, although they had told themselves not to expect it, almost all of them had been silently hoping to see a welcoming face.

Natasha squashed down the brief flash of disappointment into something unidentifiable and led the way inside.

Several employees greeted them, and a janitor professed that he was glad the team were back, but when they all stepped into the elevator and the silver doors slid shut, all they could feel was awkward silence.

“So much for Tony,” Clint snorted.

Bucky rubbed his metal arm, a tad nervously. After all, this would be only his second visit to the Tower. Tony had waved a hand in the air and proclaimed the events of the “Civil War” over, but he had been remarkably reluctant to join the team on missions. And they’d only really dropped by the Tower once after for a few hours for a team meeting when the Accords had been mended, so bonding time had been overlooked.

For now, though, Natasha was going to take Tony at his word and assume they were welcome. She had bigger things to worry about. Like sleep.

“Level 98, Avengers quarters,” FRIDAY chimed as the doors eased open. “Please keep your voice down.”

They drabbled into the room, too physically drained to think carefully about what the AI had told them. Natasha made a beeline for the room she’d stayed in before, and to her pleasure it was still plainly hers. The bed was oak and the handles of the bedside cabinets were steel. She lit one of the large lamps angled next to the bed and sighed gratefully.

Clint made a choking noise just outside the bedroom door.

Natasha let her stuff fall on the floor and slipped back down the hallway. The team were huddled together behind the glowingly polished island bench of a large kitchen, staring open-mouthed at the living space adjoining.

Natasha blinked. A man was asleep on the lounge.

No, Tony Stark was asleep on the lounge. Tony Stark, a qualified insomniac, who had once stayed up for ninety-six hours straight, was wrapped in a blanket with his feet up and his head back, honest-to-god snoring.

Clint made the choking sound again.

“Wow,” was Bruce’s only reaction. He sounded vaguely impressed.

Bucky shook his head. “This does not match the image of Tony Stark I was given by you lot,” he reprimanded, glancing at the list of movie credits still scrolling on the TV screen. “I never-- wait. Is that a kid?”

Natasha looked more closely. She first saw hints of a second person in the sock poking out of the blanket at a strange angle, and the pale hand with curled-up fingers resting on Tony’s chest. Then she found a head of what looked like brown curls, tucked snugly under Tony’s arm. And eventually, a second set of sleeping breaths, slow and light.

It looked so… intimate. Tony’s face was so gentle. Softer than Natasha had ever seen. He was wearing a T-shirt instead of a suit, and Natasha could’ve sworn the man slept in his suit. He had one hand clutching the blanket and the other with his fingers woven through the kid’s hair.

“Holy shit,” Sam said. “That’s a kid.”

The Avengers stared at each other.

“Not just that,” Rhodey added disbelievingly, and pointed. “You see the hoodie that kid’s wearing? Well, I’d know that hoodie anywhere. That’s Tones’ precious MIT jumper. Most favourite piece of clothing he owns.”

Clint finally found his voice. “But Tony never shares his jumpers.”

Natasha nodded. “We know…”

Eventually they had been standing there long enough with their mouths open that Rhodey felt the need to do something. He ushered the team down the hallway and into the room set aside for him.

They gathered around the bed.

“Stark and a kid,” Sam was repeating. “That was a kid.”

Rhodey nodded wearily. He didn’t know what to do. This was more trouble than he’d been expecting, and that was saying something, since he’d been prepared for the outbreak of Civil War number two. He’d decided on the plane over exactly what kinds of platitudes would be needed for the team, and mentally prepared a calming speech for Tony. It wouldn’t work, of course; Tony only listened to his best friend when he was being either exceptionally wise or exceptionally stupid, but it was a good plan. Because Rhodey would do almost anything to stop the team disintegrating further. That was why he’d been by the former Rogues' sides through all the recent missions.

He knew Tony. He knew how much he’d been hurt by what the media were calling the Avenger’s Civil War. He’d witnessed Tony’s nightmares when Pepper hadn’t been there, and talked him through panic attacks in the young hours of the morning because a sound, a sight, had reminded the man of the battle. He’d been there when Tony threw up in the toilet sixteen nights in a row.

And he’d seen the blueprints of the armour that he’d worn. Complete with a shattered, jagged curve where the arc reactor should have been.

He didn’t know how the team was ever going to be that again. A team. A complete set.

Even just friendly acquaintances would be good at this point.

So the whole prevent-another-fight thing was a good plan. A plan wholly overthrown by the fact that Tony wasn’t worked up and crisising after all. In fact it was the complete opposite. He was sound asleep.

Rhodey was fairly sure he’d never even seen the man voluntarily fall asleep. And this was voluntary. That much was obvious. The way the child was nestled so safely into Tony was absolute proof. And the older man’s fingers… Tony must have fallen asleep carding gently through the kid’s curls.

To say nothing of the jumper. That was nothing short of a miracle.

It was the purest thing Rhodey had ever witnessed. And coming from Tones, also the most unexpected.

“So who’s the kid?” Steve asked.

It took Rhodey quite a minute to realise everybody in the room was staring at him.

“Why would I know?” he spluttered.

They glared at him like it was a given he could read minds.

“I mean, you’re Tony’s best friend,” Steve pointed out. “Out of everyone here you’re definitely the… closest to him.”

A slight awkwardness settled over Rhodey’s room, because of course they all once were close to Tony. It was washed mostly away by the following, “Why wouldn’t you know who the kid is?”

“But I--“ Rhodey looked at Clint, who rolled his eyes.

“I’m not going to be any help. We were all fucking criminals five months ago, remember?”

Rhodey could trace the shock residually plastered through every crease and curve of the other man’s face. Natasha still had a particularly pensive expression, sure, but Clint was floored. He looked like he had a concussion.

Maybe he did. Maybe that was a side effect of finding Tony Stark asleep on the couch next to a kid.

“We haven’t exactly been around,” Bruce admitted.

They all looked expectantly to Rhodey again.

Rhodey was confused.

“He’s just as surprised as the rest of us,” Natasha said.

Sam, who had quickly formed an opinion of his own, was caught off guard. “Stark didn’t even tell you? Damn. That must hurt.”

Clint caught on. “Turns out he didn’t really ever trust any of us...”

“Tell me what? Trust us with what?” Rhodey repeated.

“Isn’t it obvious?” Sam asked. “That was a kid.”

They all nodded and thought for a moment.

“That was his kid.”

And that single sentence summed it all up. Tony Stark had a son.

“Fuck…?” Bucky said wonderingly. “How old would he be?”

“He must be… oh, in middle school at least,” Natasha said. “Probably older. I mean, think about Stark's past.”

“Genius, billionaire, playboy, philanthropist,” Bruce mused.

“And nobody knew? Tony kept him secret this whole time?!”

“Must be,” said Bruce.

They were all beginning to freak out now.

“So for more than a decade, Stark had a child hiding out in the Tower?” Clint screeched. “And we never even noticed?”

He collapsed onto Rhodey’s bed, complaining, “I thought I was the only one with a secret family.”

“Oh god.” All eyes turned to Steve, who suddenly looked sick. “I broke his suit – when we fought in Siberia – I smashed the arc reactor and almost killed him and just left and, and…” The words spilled out at unnatural angles. His voice, already roughened, dropped lower. “And all that time he must have had a child waiting for him to come home.”

“No wonder he packed us off on missions halfway round the world as soon as he could,” Sam groaned. “He didn’t want us around his kid.”

“Good reason, too,” Steve said piously, and for the first time since Rhodey had worked with him after the Accords he looked sorry. Like all the frustration and remorse he’d had boxed up inside him was finally slipping through.

Maybe reconciliation would be easier than Rhodey had thought. And all it had taken was a sleeping kid.

A mystery sleeping kid.

“Well,” said Natasha, “I’m going to find who this kid is that Stark has conjured.”

Rhodey agreed. Whoever the hell could get Tony to sleep would be worth knowing.

He still doubted the child was actually Tony’s, but he had a sneaky suspicion that was only because he was in denial that his oldest friend had kept such a huge secret from him for so long…

There was no faking what Rhodey had seen in the living room.

Tony Stark was a father.

Tony woke to sunlight and a familiar set of sleeping breaths.

He sighed contentedly. There was warm sun on his face and his eyes were closed. They didn’t even have to open any time soonish. He’d cleared his schedule months before for the Avenger’s homecoming date; but all he was planning to do was lab time with Peter. They had a whole weekend to themselves, since May was busy. He’d been wanting to show the boy the new nanite tech he’d been working on. It would make fantastic armour. Maybe they could revamp the Spider-suit with it – give it a new name, even – what about the Iron Spider?

Ha, Rhodey would laugh at him about that.

But wait. Rhodey wasn’t here, he was off on missions with the Avengers while Tony hid away in his tower like the fucking coward he was; unable to face his parents’ brain-washed murderer and a man he’d once considered a teammate… they were coming home, though, and Tony regretted saying they could but he already had and that was all in the past now.

How did meeting them go? His brain supplied encouragingly. Surely it can’t have been as bad as you were worrying?

Wait. That was a good question. Tony wracked through his jumbled thoughts, but for the life of him he couldn’t remember meeting the Avengers last night.

What he did remember (with a sinking feeling) was Peter’s backpack spontaneously combusting and smashing the penthouse TV. Turns out the boy had somehow contaminated his school books with a variety of chemicals from the lab and also a poison-tipped knife some mugger had almost stabbed him with. The kid had an alarming penchant for getting into scrapes.

He was going to turn Tony’s hair grey one day. It was lucky neither of them were in the room at the time.

Tony had, of course, said everything was fine (except for how the hell did this kid get his backpack to explode). He could always buy another TV but in the meantime, they could go downstairs to the Avengers floor, where there was another TV.

So they did, and Peter fell asleep halfway through the movie and then Tony supposed he did too, which meant—

Fuck.

He hadn’t met the Avengers last night.

Double fuck.

It felt a bit like two parallel lines had crossed – one world where Tony had the Avengers and one where Tony had Peter. How the hell had two schedules collided so abysmally?

He’d been thinking about this weekend in two separate contexts for months.

God, he was an idiot. He’d fallen asleep in the Avenger’s fucking living room.

So had Peter.

Tony was trying to protect Peter. Not push him into the spotlight to be judged. Oh, he’d royally screwed up.

He opened his eyes.

Yep. The Avenger’s living room.

Tony looked down at Peter, who’d somehow wriggled into the crook of his arm. The kid’s breaths were deep and even. Tony really didn’t want to wake him up, but he couldn’t just leave him here for the Avengers to find and obsess over.

God, that would be a disaster.

“Peter,” he murmured, running a thumb along his arm. “Pete, buddy, wake up.”

“Mmph,” the kid said sleepily.

Tony hid a smile. “Peter, you gotta get up.”

“Why?”

Oh crap. Hadn’t thought this through very well, had he? “Well. Uh. You want some breakfast?”

“’Sit morning yet?”

“Yeah, buddy, it’s morning. Or maybe noon, eyeing that sunshine. How ‘bout you go back upstairs and have a shower while I get some food going?”

“Mm sleepy,” Peter grumbled adorably.

“Yeah, I know.” Please just go upstairs before they find you. Please, I don’t know what I’d do; don’t know what they’d do, I don’t trust them anymore— “C’mon, buddy.” He sat up and rubbed his neck. “You gave me a stiff neck.”

“Stop falling asleep on the couch, then,” Peter replied, yawning.

“Well, I’d try, but there’s this annoying Spider-kid that seems to like falling asleep on me. Terrible, y’know? But what can I do?”

“Mr Stark,” Peter protested.

“Go have a shower,” Tony replied. “Lab day, remember?”

The kid perked up a lot and raced towards the elevator. As the doors closed Tony let go of a breath he hadn’t realised he’d been holding. Now, to get out of here himself without being seen…

That plan didn’t last long. Tony turned around, still wearing a hoodie, trackpants, and socks, with the couch blanket wrapped around his shoulders and looking (if he did say so himself) almost disgustingly domestic; opened the door, and was met with a waiting circle of not-very-happy Avengers.

Boom. Ambushed.

Tony’s heart sank right down into his feet.

“Good morning,” Clint snarked. “Wasn’t expecting you to wake up anytime soon. Looked like you needed the sleep.”

Shit. They’d seen him. Had they seen Peter?

“Ah,” he tried, “my tower, my rules.”

“You said you were going to come and say hello, Stark.”

“I said maybe I would. I was- uh, working in the lab?”

“Doesn’t explain why we found you out cold in our living room.”

“Let’s cut to the chase,” Natasha decided. A hush settled. “Who’s the kid?”

They saw him.

Oh fuck.

“Well. Uh.”

It wasn’t often Tony was lost for words. But this was one of those times.

How was he supposed to describe Peter? And how was he supposed to explain what Peter meant to him, to the Avengers, who were all convinced (with the possible exception of Rhodey) he was an asshole?

Peter was… Spider-Man, obviously, though he couldn’t tell them that. A random kid he’d tracked to Queens. A genius, to make those webs that had the tensile strength to pretty much hold two halves of a ferry together and were so sticky Tony had spent five memorable hours holding onto a screwdriver from scratch using only whatever chemicals his science teacher wouldn’t miss. The kid was possibly smarter than Tony.

He was a mentee. A protegee. Somebody Tony could pass his experience to. But more than that.

He was—oh crap.

Peter felt like Tony’s kid.

Not a kid.

His kid.

But he wasn’t, and Tony didn’t have the right to parent him. To be a dad.

No, they were mentor/mentee. Nothing more.

“He’s my intern,” Tony said weakly.

They glared at him.

“Really?” asked Rhodey, who looked slightly confused.

“No, he’s not,” Natasha snapped. “I know what a lie sounds like.”

“Tell the truth, Stark,” Sam admonished.

“He’s—” Tony struggled. “Stop questioning me!”

If only he’d gotten an extra few hours of sleep. Maybe then he’d have the brain capacity to leave this situation.

“Ah. Guys?” Bruce asked. They turned and looked at him. “Give Tony some space. We’re in his home, after all.”

“He’s yours, isn’t he?” Rhodey asked quietly. “Your son.”

Tony opened and closed his mouth. Like a fish. “No?”

A pause. Nobody looked like they believed him. “No! NO! No, he’s not mine. He’s an intern. Just an intern.”

Clint blinked. “Exactly how dumb do you think we are?”

Now wasn’t a good time to antagonise people. “Very?” Dammit, you smartass mouth.

“Tony?”

The man turned, socks sliding over the floor. And came face-to-face with Steve.

Captain fucking America.

Great.

“I just wanted to say sorry,” the bigger man said humbly.

Tony scoffed.

“I’m really, truly sorry. Nothing can make what I did alright. Nothing ever will. But for the little it’s worth, I’m sorry for lying to you. And fighting you.”

Bucky looked at Tony—shyly?

“I’m—I’m sorry too,” the other man whispered.

Tony left without another word, fuming.

 

Upstairs, he checked with FRIDAY first to ensure none of the Avengers had tried to follow him (into his very private penthouse, fuck them); which luckily none of them had. Then he asked FRIDAY to ban them from the penthouse floor.

She did.

Then he turned on the stovetop, and got out a frying pan, and went into something Peter knowingly called his “stress cooking phase”, where his body was on autopilot. Peter said some of the most interesting meals he’d ever tasted were from when Tony stress-cooked. And that was saying something, because he’d seen the kid gulp down a very questionable-looking biscuit a fan had baked him once. Not to mention his Aunt’s cooking (if that can be labelled as such).

No, Tony’s stress-cooking was delicious. Delicious but a little strange.

Peter came out of the shower just as Tony felt like he’d woken up. The kid was wearing a new pair of pants and undoubtedly another dorky science T-shirt, but Tony couldn’t see that because his own MIT jumper was in the way.

“You ever going to take that thing off, kid?” he asked, amused.

Peter slid onto a stool at the breakfast bench and accepted the plate Tony handed him. “Nope.”
